repository.description: Repository for the main Cryostat container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the main Cryostat container image

tag.description: Tag for the main Cryostat container image

type.description: Type of Service to create for the Cryostat application

httpPort.description: Port number to expose on the Service for Cryostat's HTTP server

level.description: Log level for troubleshooting and debugging

sslProxied.description: Enables SSL Proxied Environment Variables, useful when you are offloading SSL/TLS at External Loadbalancer instead of Ingress

enabled.description: Whether to create an Ingress object for the Cryostat service

className.description: Ingress class name for the Cryostat application Ingress

tls.description: TLS configuration for the Cryostat application Ingress. See: [IngressSpec](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/service-resources/ingress-v1/#IngressSpec)

enabled.description: Whether to create a Route object for the Cryostat service. Available only on OpenShift
Whether to secure the Cryostat application Route with TLS. See: [TLSConfig](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.10/rest_api/network_apis/route-route-openshift-io-v1.html#spec-tls)

termination.description: Type of TLS termination to use for the Cryostat application Route. One of: `edge`, `passthrough`, `reencrypt`

insecureEdgeTerminationPolicy.description: Specify how to handle insecure traffic for the Cryostat application Route. One of: `Allow`, `Disable`, `Redirect`

key.description: Custom private key to use when securing the Cryostat application Route

certificate.description: Custom certificate to use when securing the Cryostat application Route

caCertificate.description: Custom CA certificate to use, if needed to complete the certificate chain, when securing the Cryostat application Route

destinationCACertificate.description: Provides the contents of the CA certificate of the final destination when using reencrypt termination for the Cryostat application Route

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the Cryostat container. See: [ResourceRequirements](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#resources)

memory.description: Memory resource request for the Cryostat container

databaseSecretName.description: Name of the secret containing database keys. This secret must contain a USERNAME secret which is the database connection username, a CONNECTION_KEY secret which is the database connection password, and an ENCRYPTION_KEY secret which is the key used to encrypt sensitive data stored within the database, such as the target credentials keyring. It must not be updated across chart upgrades. It is recommended that the secret should be marked as immutable to avoid accidental changes to secret's data. More details: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/secret/#secret-immutable

installNamespaceDisabled.description: When false and `namespaces` is empty, the Cryostat application will default to discovery targets in the install namespace (i.e. `{{ .Release.Namespace }}`)

allowAllNamespaces.description: When true, this overrides the `core.discovery.kubernetes.namespaces` list and configures the Cryostat application to monitor all namespaces in the cluster. This requires elevated permissions to create a ClusterRole and ClusterRoleBinding, which will be done automatically if the `rbac.create` value is `true`. WARNING: This allows Cryostat to discover, and potentially connect to and collect data from, applications in *any* Namespace in the cluster. ALL users with access to this Cryostat instance will be able to read data from potentially any application in the cluster. For data security and isolation concerns it is recommended to leave this setting disabled, and instead install multiple Cryostat instances with lists of target namespaces, and apply sensible access controls for users to each instance as needed

namespaces.description: List of namespaces whose workloads the Cryostat application should be permitted to access and profile

builtInPortNamesDisabled.description: When false and `portNames` is empty, the Cryostat application will use the default port name `jfr-jmx` to look for JMX connectable targets

portNames.description: List of port names that the Cryostat application should look for in order to consider a target as JMX connectable

builtInPortNumbersDisabled.description: When false and `portNumbers` is empty, the Cryostat application will use the default port number `9091` to look for JMX connectable targets

portNumbers.description: List of port numbers that the Cryostat application should look for in order to consider a target as JMX connectable

fsMode.description: default filesystem mode (permissions) for declarative configuration volumes

secretNames.description: List of Secret names. Each Secret is expected to contain one or more files, which are json Stored Credentials, to be mounted to the Cryostat container

configMapNames.description: List of ConfigMap names. Each ConfigMap is expected to contain one or more files, which are automated rule definitions, to be mounted to the Cryostat container
List of ConfigMap names. Each ConfigMap is expected to contain one or more files, which are XML JMC Agent Probe Templates, to be mounted to the Cryostat container
List of ConfigMap names. Each ConfigMap is expected to contain one or more files, which are .jfc (XML) JFR Event Templates, to be mounted to the Cryostat container

secretNames.description: List of Secret names. Each Secret is expected to contain one or more files, which are TLS certificates which target applications may use for their JMX servers, to be mounted to the Cryostat container for its TLS truststore

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for main Cryostat container container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for main Cryostat container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

tolerations.description: Tolerations for the Cryostat Pod. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)

repository.description: Repository for the Report Generator container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the Report Generator container image

tag.description: Tag for the Report Generator image

type.description: Type of Service to create for the Report Generator Deployment

httpPort.description: Port number to expose on the Service for the Report Generator Deployment

reportsSecretName.description: Name of the secret containing the report generator access keys. This secret must contain a REPORTS_PASS secret which is the secret credential for the report generators. It must not be updated across chart upgrades, or else the connection between Cryostat and report generators will not be able to initialize. It is recommended that the secret should be marked as immutable to avoid accidental changes to secret's data. More details: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/secret/#secret-immutable

level.description: Log level for troubleshooting and debugging

replicas.description: Number of Report Generator replicas to deploy. If zero, the Deployment and Service will not be created and the main Cryostat container will handle all report generations on its own

cpu.description: CPU resource request for each Pod in the Report Generator Deployment

memory.description: Memory resource request for each Pod in the Report Generator Deployment

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the Report Generator container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the Report Generator container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

tolerations.description: Tolerations for the Report Generator Pods. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)

repository.description: Repository for the database container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the database container image

tag.description: Tag for the database container image

url.description: URL to the database instance. This can be an in-cluster self-hosted instance with a hostname like db.myapp.local, or it can be an external commercial service. This should be a complete JDBC URL with scheme, host, and port. User authentication information should be provided using a *Secret* and *core.databaseSecretName*. If this URL is not specified then a managed [cryostat-db](https://github.com/cryostatio/cryostat-db) instance will be automatically deployed and configured. If an unmanaged database instance is specified here then other database configuration settings (Pod annotations, Service configurations) do not apply. The database must be a Postgres instance with the pgcrypto extension enabled.

type.description: Type of Service to create for the database

port.description: Port number to expose on the Service

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the database container. See: [ResourceRequirements](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#resources)

memory.description: Memory resource request for the database container

enabled.description: Specify whether to use persistentVolumeClaim (true) or EmptyDir storage (false). This is recommended to be enabled, but the storage size and selector should be chosen carefully first

storage.description: Storage size to request for the persistentVolumeClaim

accessModes.description: Access mode for the persistentVolumeClaim. See: [Access Modes](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/persistent-volumes/#persistentvolumeclaims)

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the database container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the database container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

tolerations.description: Tolerations for the Database Pod. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)

repository.description: Repository for the storage container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the storage container image

tag.description: Tag for the storage container image

storageSecretName.description: Name of the secret containing the object storage secret access key. This secret must contain a STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY secret which is the object storage secret access key. It must not be updated across chart upgrades, or else the connection between Cryostat components and object storage will not be able to initialize. If using an external S3 provider requiring authentication then this **must** be provided. It is recommended that the secret should be marked as immutable to avoid accidental changes to secret's data. More details: [Kubernetes Secrets](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/secret/#secret-immutable)

url.description: URL to the S3 object storage provider instance. This can be an in-cluster self-hosted instance with a hostname like s3.storage.local, or it can be an external commercial service. This should include scheme, host, and port. User authenication information should be provided using a *Secret* and *storage.storageSecretName*. If this is not specified then a managed [cryostat-storage](https://github.com/cryostatio/cryostat-storage) instance will be automatically deployed and configured. If an unmanaged S3 instance is specified here then other storage configuration settings (such as at-rest encryption, Pod annotations, Service configurations) do not apply. Production installations of Cryostat should not rely on `cryostat-storage`

useChecksumValidation.description: whether PUT object request checksum validations are used. These should normally be enabled, but are known to cause issues with SeaweedFS/cryostat-storage and later S3 SDK versions. This is *true* by default when storage.provider.url is configured, but if not configured and cryostat-storage is deployed then this will be taken as *false*.

usePathStyleAccess.description: whether path-style accesses are used for ex. object buckets. If path style access is not used then DNS subdomain resolution will be used. This is *true* by default for broader compatibility for low-footprint storage container installations, but subdomain resolution generally offers better performance if it is available and may be required for use with commercial storage providers.

usePresignedRecordingTransfers.description: whether object storage presigned GET URLs should be used for transferring files between Cryostat components (ex. for automated analysis report generation). If this is disabled then Cryostat will act as a "network pipe" between other components and handle streaming file contents. This is *true* by default to reduce network utilization and request latency

usePresignedDownloads.description: whether object storage presigned GET URLs should be used for downloading files via the user's browser. If this is disabled then Cryostat will act as a "network pipe" between storage and the user's browser and handle streaming file contents. If the object storage URLs are not accessible from the user's network location then this must be disabled, otherwise enabling it will reduce network utilization and request latency. This is *false* by default

region.description: S3 object storage provider region. This may be used by the storage provider to geolocate the physical storage in a particular region for regulatory, performance, or cost reasons

credentialsType.description: configuration for how the S3 client will locate credentials for the S3 service. See: [Quarkus S3 client](https://docs.quarkiverse.io/quarkus-amazon-services/dev/amazon-s3.html#)

trustAll.description: enable this to disable TLS certificate verification on the S3 client

storageMode.description: the strategy Cryostat will use for storing files' metadata. The default 'tagging' strategy stores all metadata as object Tags. The 'metadata' strategy stores metadata as object Metadata, which is immutable but allows for more entries than Tags. The 'bucket' strategy stores metadata as separate files (ex. JSON object maps) in a dedicated bucket, with prefixes to differentiate the kind of object the metadata belongs to.

archivedRecordings.description: the name of the storage bucket containing archived Flight Recordings

archivedReports.description: the name of the storage bucket containing the Automated Analysis Report for archived Flight Recordings

eventTemplates.description: the name of the storage bucket containing Custom Event Templates

jmcAgentProbeTemplates.description: the name of the storage bucket containing JMC Agent Probe Templates

threadDumps.description: the name of the storage bucket containing archived Thread Dumps

heapDumps.description: the name of the storage bucket containing archived Heap Dumps

metadata.description: the name of the storage bucket containing files' metadata. Only used if storage.provider.metadata.storageMode is set to 'bucket'.

enabled.description: Enable at-rest encryption of stored objects. The storage container will generate a secret key for each stored object and use this key to encrypt and decrypt objects transparently. The key is written to the object metadata, so in the default storage container configuration this only adds a small layer of additional security. This is only used for the managed cryostat-storage instance and will have no effect if an external, unmanaged storage provider is configured.

type.description: Type of Service to create for the object storage

port.description: Port number to expose on the Service

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the object storage container. See: [ResourceRequirements](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#resources)

memory.description: Memory resource request for the object storage container

enabled.description: Specify whether to use persistentVolumeClaim (true) or EmptyDir storage (false). This is recommended to be enabled, but the storage size and selector should be chosen carefully first

storage.description: Storage size to request for the persistentVolumeClaim

accessModes.description: Access mode for the persistentVolumeClaim. See: [Access Modes](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/persistent-volumes/#persistentvolumeclaims)

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the object storage container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the object storage container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

tolerations.description: Tolerations for the Storage Pod. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)

repository.description: Repository for the Grafana container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the Grafana container image

tag.description: Tag for the Grafana container image

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the Grafana container. See: [ResourceRequirements](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#resources)

memory.description: Memory resource request for the Grafana container

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for for the Grafana container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the Grafana container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

tolerations.description: Tolerations for the Grafana Pod. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)

repository.description: Repository for the JFR Data Source container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the JFR Data Source container image

tag.description: Tag for the JFR Data Source container image

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the JFR Data Source container. See: [ResourceRequirements](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#resources)

memory.description: Memory resource request for the JFR Data Source container

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for for the JFR Data Source container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the JFR Data Source container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

tolerations.description: Tolerations for the JFR Datasource Pod. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)

repository.description: Repository for the OAuth2 Proxy container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the OAuth2 Proxy container image

tag.description: Tag for the OAuth2 Proxy container image

enabled.description: Whether a self-signed TLS certificate for oauth2-proxy HTTPS is generated and used

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the OAuth2 Proxy container

memory.description: Memory resource request for the OAuth2 Proxy container

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the OAuth2 Proxy container. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the OAuth2 Proxy container. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the OAuth2 Proxy container **only in the Cryostat main pod**

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the OAuth2 Proxy container **only in the Cryostat main pod**

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the OAuth2 Proxy container **only in the report generator pods**

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the OAuth2 Proxy container **only in the report generator pods**

cookieSecretName.description: Name of the secret containing the authenticating proxy cookie encryption key. This secret must contain a COOKIE_SECRET secret which is the cookie encryption key. It must not be updated across chart upgrades, or else existing user login sessions will be invalidated. It is recommended that the secret should be marked as immutable to avoid accidental changes to secret's data. More details: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/secret/#secret-immutable

enabled.description: Whether the OAuth Proxy deployed for securing Cryostat's Pods should be one that integrates with OpenShift-specific features, or a generic one

name.description: The name of the ClusterRole to bind for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy

enabled.description: Whether Cryostat should use basic authentication for users. When false, Cryostat will not perform any form of authentication

secretName.description: Name of the Secret that contains the credentials within Cryostat's namespace **(Required if basicAuth is enabled)**

filename.description: Key within Secret containing the `htpasswd` file. The file should contain one user definition entry per line, with the syntax "user:passHash", where "user" is the username and "passHash" is the `bcrypt` hash of the desired password. Such an entry can be generated with ex. `htpasswd -nbB username password` **(Required if basicAuth is enabled)**

repository.description: Repository for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy container image

pullPolicy.description: Image pull policy for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy container image

tag.description: Tag for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy container image

cpu.description: CPU resource request for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy container

memory.description: Memory resource request for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy container

enabled.description: Whether the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview role checks for users and clients are enabled. If this is disabled then the proxy will only check that the user has valid credentials or holds a valid token

group.description: The OpenShift resource group that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for. See https://github.com/openshift/oauth-proxy/?tab=readme-ov-file#delegate-authentication-and-authorization-to-openshift-for-infrastructure

resource.description: The OpenShift resource that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for

subresource.description: The OpenShift resource that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for

name.description: The OpenShift resource name that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for

namespace.description: The OpenShift namespace that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for

verb.description: The OpenShift resource name that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for

version.description: The OpenShift resource version that the SubjectAccessReview/TokenAccessReview will be performed for

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy. See: [Define Environment Variables](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/define-environment-variable-container/)

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy. See: [Define Environment Variables From ConfigMap](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-pod-configmap/#configure-all-key-value-pairs-in-a-configmap-as-container-environment-variables)

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy **only in the Cryostat main pod**

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy **only in the Cryostat main pod**

envVars.description: Extra environment variables for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy **only in the report generator pods**

envSources.description: Sources for extra variables for the OpenShift OAuth Proxy **only in the report generator pods**

imagePullSecrets.description: Image pull secrets to be used for the Cryostat deployment

nameOverride.description: Overrides the name of this Chart

fullnameOverride.description: Overrides the fully qualified application name of `[release name]-[chart name]`

create.description: Specifies whether RBAC resources should be created
Specifies whether a service account should be created

name.description: The name of the service account to use. If not set and create is true, a name is generated using the fullname template

enabled.description: whether a NetworkPolicy for restricting Cryostat component Pods' traffic is installed. This prevents other Pods from sending unwanted traffic to Cryostat's Pods. Traffic should flow via the Service (or Route, or other Ingress) only, not by directly targeting Pods

tolerations.description: default Tolerations for the various Pods. See: [Tolerations](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/workload-resources/pod-v1/#scheduling)
